name: Devoted Paladin
lsvDescription: You have to be pretty aggressive to want this, but it's a good curve-topper in those cases. It also does a great job of showcasing a good Paladin ability, making me think that Paladins translate better than most classes to Magic.

name: Half-Elf Monk
lsvDescription: The Monk looks like the kind of card that overperforms – it can block well, attack and use its ability and lock down their biggest threat. I also really like the flavor, as Monks being annoying really translates well. This runs around the map stunning things, but not actually doing much damage and being very hard to kill.

name: Dawnbringer Cleric
lsvDescription: Dawnbringer Cleric brings a lot to the table, and even if each ability isn't a game-breaker, having access to all three is quite strong. I also love the flavor, as each ability perfectly mirrors the D&D equivalent, giving this a perfect score there. The only thing that doesn't line up is how our D&D party points Dispel Magic at literally everything they can't figure out, but I don't think that particular habit needed representing.

name: Blink Dog
lsvDescription: If you have enough ways to buff the Blink Dog, it can do some good work, but by itself, its bark is worse than its bite. Phasing for four mana isn't a great ability either, even if it does have awesome flavor.

name: Earth-Cult Elemental
lsvDescription: This is another expensive die roll card, which makes me not very excited to play it. If you need more ways to trigger your stuff, this plays, but the output of both players saccing or them doing so is not that powerful.

name: The Book of Exalted Deeds
lsvDescription: If you don't have life gain in your deck, The Book is basically a blank. However, it becomes disgusting once you can reliably trigger it, and you can eventually cash it out if you have to. The flavor works for me too, as it feels epic, summons Angels and rewards good deeds (of sorts).

name: Sepulcher Ghoul
lsvDescription: Sepulcher Ghoul is reasonably-sized and lets you trigger morbid or death triggers at will. That's enough for me, and I've played this in any creature-heavy deck and felt fine about it.

name: Zariel, Archduke of Avernus
lsvDescription: Zariel does a good job of locking up the ground, and the +1 ability can be really threatening if you're attacking. That's a solid combination, even if the ultimate is mediocre, making Zariel a threat in any game where you aren't losing to flyers. The flavor is great too, as she's a commander in the war of Devils against Demons, while also being known for a rash and aggressive nature.

name: Minion of the Mighty
lsvDescription: The flavor is sweet here, and I especially like that the Minion probably dies when it summons a Dragon. For this to work in Limited, you'd need to have this, a Dragon, six power of creatures and not be able to just cast the Dragon. That's not a parley I'm interested in betting on.

name: Hill Giant Herdgorger
lsvDescription: Just look at that delicious mutton flavor – I bet this guy enjoys a good MLT. It's also a great finisher for ramp decks, as three life goes a long way in stabilizing the board and reducing risk.

name: Werewolf Pack Leader
lsvDescription: Werewolf Pack Leader is an absolute beating if you cast it early, and still does some work later in the game. That's the recipe for a premium two-drop, even if it falls a bit short of being a bomb.

name: Hall of Storm Giants
lsvDescription: Lands that animate are always good, and all of these are strong additions to your deck. The white and blue ones are probably the best, and the black one is the worst, but realistically you should be taking and playing these all around third through fifth pick.

name: Zombie Ogre
lsvDescription: I'm not sure what the flavor is here, though the card does good work in venture decks. It's especially brutal when paired with removal like Precipitous Drop, and I've gone on Dungeon speedruns thanks to this. Morbid decks can use it well also, and overall this has decent stats and a good ability, even if it is a bit clunky.

name: Wight
lsvDescription: Wight is a 3/2 for two that gets a lot of value if it ever gets into combat with another creature. Note that this ability works well on blocks too, making this a great card for any black deck.

name: Minimus Containment
lsvDescription: Minimus Containment is very close to Oblivion Ring, and even though it gives them a Treasure, if they use that Treasure, they're giving up on ever getting their thing back. That's a good card, and one I'll happily take. The flavor is on point too, as one of the modes of the Imprisonment spell does exactly this

name: Demogorgon's Clutches
lsvDescription: I've so far not liked main-decking Mind Rot, so this isn't a high priority. The extra mill and life loss helps, making this a little more appealing in attacking decks.

name: Nadaar, Selfless Paladin
lsvDescription: Nadaar is one of the stronger venture cards, both making it easier to complete a Dungeon and rewarding you for doing so. This also feels quite paladin-like, making it a flavor win on top of being a strong build-around.

name: Owlbear
lsvDescription: Owlbear plays great, as it's a huge monster that replaces itself and has very relevant stats. The flavor is a miss for me, but they can't all be winners.

name: Eyes of the Beholder
lsvDescription: Beholders have 11 eyes (10 eye stalks plus the central one), so this is a great flavor fit. It's a bit clunky, making it a card I'm not that excited to actually play, but it is removal if you need it.

name: Xorn
lsvDescription: Xorn is a fantastic card in the RB Treasure deck, and decent in any deck that has a few ways to make Treasure. It'll get you a little value and then trade off, which is a great place to be. Flavor-wise, Xorns love eating gems, so it would actually have worked if Rust Monster was named Xorn instead, since this concept doesn't fit with how most encounters with Xorns go (them demanding your Treasure).

name: Bar the Gate
lsvDescription: Counterspells aren't usually great, but the bar gets a little lower once they have some value tacked on. This can stop them from developing while progressing your dreams of being an adventurer, but gets pretty bad against wary opponents.

name: Potion of Healing
lsvDescription: I'd only play this if I wanted to up my artifact count or had life gain synergies, as it's not quite worth it solo. I really like the flavor, because drinking a potion in D&D is a free action, which drawing a card does a good job of emulating.

name: Lair of the Hydra
lsvDescription: Lands that animate are always good, and all of these are strong additions to your deck. The white and blue ones are probably the best, and the black one is the worst, but realistically you should be taking and playing these all around third through fifth pick.

name: Gloom Stalker
lsvDescription: The payoff for completing a Dungeon isn't amazing here, which means you should be able to pick these up relatively easily. Flavor-wise, I like that it becomes a seasoned adventurer once it survives a dungeon pass and “levels up” into double strike.

name: Temple of the Dragon Queen
lsvDescription: Both these are essentially the same card, though the Temple has a lot more text. They are both five-color fixers where you choose a color and stick to it, and both are fine pickups for two-color decks (and critical for three or more color ones).

name: Trickster's Talisman
lsvDescription: This feels appropriately tricky, and gives you a decent reward for getting a creature through.  The +1/+1 helps get your 4/4 past theirs, and throwing this on a flyer isn't the worst either. I'd want a lot of creatures and some ways to get them through (pump, removal, evasion) before playing this, but most decks will be able to supply that.

name: Purple Worm
lsvDescription: Purple Worms are gigantic and devour many a beast or adventurer, so I buy this flavor-wise, and it's a steal if you ever get it for just five mana. Even at seven, it's a solid threat, and the high-roll games where you play this on turn five are going to be huge blowouts.

name: Arcane Investigator
lsvDescription: Two-drop dorks with powerful mana sink abilities used to be fantastic, but my appetite for these has gone down dramatically. You just don't run out of cards to play in modern Limited formats, and the scenarios where this would be good are few and far between. If you have to play this, it'll be fine, but my perception is that this isn't great.

name: Sorcerer Class
lsvDescription: I don't really get this card. It pushes you to have a lot of creatures and a lot of spells, with kind of strange payoffs all around (plus a Faithless Looting to start). This isn't good, and I don't understand how it connects to Sorcerers either.

name: Hoard Robber
lsvDescription: The flavor outpaces the card, as getting a 1/3 through isn't the easiest, and it's not like there's some massive payoff at the end.

name: Xanathar, Guild Kingpin
lsvDescription: As a connected crime boss with eyes everywhere (both figuratively and literally), Xanathar is a home run. If the opponent doesn't kill this the turn you play it, Xanathar's ability means they are never drawing an answer – if their top card sucks, just don't cast it. This is so good it actually seems unfun, and I don't think it's beatable if not immediately dealt with.

name: Wandering Troubadour
lsvDescription: Wandering Troubadour wins the game single-lutedly when left unchecked, and is a pretty good combatant when needed. It's worth picking early, as who doesn't want to hear tales of valiant adventuring every turn?

name: Ebondeath, Dracolich
lsvDescription: Ebondeath would be a beating even if it didn't come back from the dead, and it's trivially easy to bring back. I'd always play this in my deck and it would strongly pull me towards black, even in Pack 2, but you can make it even better if you include a couple sac outlets.

name: Circle of Dreams Druid
lsvDescription: Triple green is just too much. By the time you manage to cast this, the mana ramp is often not that useful, and I'd pretty much never play this unless I was somehow mono-green or very close to it.

name: Veteran Dungeoneer
lsvDescription: It doesn't get more solid than this. Unless you have no interest in adventuring, this will always be a good addition to your deck, and the flavor is equally on point.

name: Blue Dragon
lsvDescription: Blue Dragon offers a huge flying threat and a guarantee that attacks next turn won't be very good. It also helps your attackers get through blockers, though that's not going to come up as much as the defensive version.

name: Drider
lsvDescription: Drider is pretty beefy, and plays good defense thanks to reach. It's also a good threat as an attacker, as the opponent always has to watch out for a timely removal spell that could push it through and generate value.

name: Icingdeath, Frost Tyrant
lsvDescription: Icingdeath is a must-kill threat for only four mana, and when it dies, you get an Equipment that dominates the board. That's a bomb in my book, and it's cheap enough that you'll be able to cast it in basically every game where you don't get totally screwed. It does fit better in aggressive decks, but any deck is vastly improved by adding this. It also tells a good story, as this is how Drizzt got his legendary sword.

name: Asmodeus the Archfiend
lsvDescription: I've gotten to play with Asmodeus, and I left feeling sorely disappointed. It turns out that making a deal with the devil is bad for you after all, and this played out like a Colossal Dreadmaw with a drawback. You now have to pay for every card you draw, and even though Asmodeus gives you access to a bunch of them, it's not worth it.

name: Cave of the Frost Dragon
lsvDescription: Lands that animate are always good, and all of these are strong additions to your deck. The white and blue ones are probably the best, and the black one is the worst, but realistically you should be taking and playing these all around third through fifth pick.

name: Drizzt Do'Urden
lsvDescription: As a truly legendary figure in D&D, Drizzt delivers. You get essentially 10 power in combat right away, with the room for growth, and it's split up over multiple cards. Drizzt is a beating, and it's nearly impossible for the opponent to answer this without losing cards (and usually a bunch of life).

name: Grand Master of Flowers
lsvDescription: I wrote a highlight on Bahamut here, and suffice to say, the card is awesome. In Limited, you’ll soon get to seven loyalty thanks to the multiple protection abilities this has, and if you can pick up even one Monk, you’ll be very happy with the Grand Master. Very few creatures can dodge the lockdown ability, and once this hits seven, you get to run rampant, making this a very high pick. I also love the flavor, especially once I learned that the seven golden birds are actually Polymorphed Gold Dragons that accompany Bahamut – easily the coolest thing I learned all day.

name: Dungeon Map
lsvDescription: This is a bit clunky for most decks, but I've had a couple where it's playable. You want to value the ramp a lot and the venture part at least a little, at which point this is a good option.

name: Brazen Dwarf
lsvDescription: I've been relatively unimpressed with the dice-rolling cards overall (having drafted the deck now three times in two days), and this is one of the casualties. It's a fine card, as it blocks for a while and pings the opponent, but it's not strong enough to properly be called a payoff.

name: Compelled Duel
lsvDescription: The “target creature has to block” cards tend to be fairly weak, and this is no exception. It just takes too many things to line up right for it to work and the fail cases are really bad.

name: Herald of Hadar
lsvDescription: Herald of Hadar is the endgame plan you get if you haven't found anything great, as these are readily available and always passable. The activation is expensive enough that you have to dedicate your whole turn to it, and it's not powerful enough that you won't do that unless you have absolutely nothing else going on. The flavor is solid too, as Hadar is an evil star monster that consumes matter incessantly.

name: Dungeon Crawler
lsvDescription: I can't get over how good this name is, and the card itself isn't bad either. A 2/1 for one is decent to begin with, even if it can't block the turn you play it, and gives you some nice value for completing a Dungeon.

name: Elturgard Ranger
lsvDescription: Elturgard Ranger offers a lot of stats for a reasonable price, and reach on a 4/1 makes for a good blocker. There will be times when this gets exploited, as one-toughness is rough, but it's still worth playing in most decks that aren't glutted at five mana.

name: Shortcut Seeker
lsvDescription: A 2/5 for four is big enough to brawl reasonably well, but won't get through very many times in a game (if any). I don't mind playing this if you're light on creatures, but it's not what I'm seeking.

name: Eccentric Apprentice
lsvDescription: Like Displacer Beast, this is an efficient way to get some venturing going. It also pays you off nicely for a Dungeon finish, either granting one of your own saboteurs flying or shrinking one of their things. Note the target doesn't lose its abilities, so this can lead to some weird places.

name: Armory Veteran
lsvDescription: If you need a two-drop, why not pick up this unremarkable henchman that's going to trade off in a forgettable fashion? It needs Equipment to be solid, and even then is a card you play because you have to, not because you want to.

name: Ochre Jelly
lsvDescription: The gameplay of slashing the jelly into pieces, each of which gets smaller and smaller, is awesome. The card itself is great too, as a five-mana 4/4 that dies into a 2/2 and then a 1/1 is solid, and there's the potential for more. I'd try and cast this for X=4 at minimum, as it's a lot weaker if you don't get it to 4/4 at least.

name: Wish
lsvDescription: This card is unplayable in Limited, as three mana on top of a sideboard card is a terrible deal. I have to say that this flavor doesn't do it for me either – it does capture the Magic version of Wish, but not the D&D version. Wish is a ninth level spell, one of the most powerful in the entire game, and a retread of previous Magic Wish cards doesn't feel right to me. I'd have liked to see something amazing and epic, and this isn't it. Wish is the biggest flavor fail in the set for my tastes.

name: Minsc, Beloved Ranger
lsvDescription: I hadn't run across the story of Minsc before, but this card nails it. It's a pretty good one, so I'd check it out if you're a fan of lore. As for the card, the main issue here is of course the casting cost. If you can cast Minsc reliably, he's awesome, as a 3/3 plus a 1/1 plus a strong pump ability is well worth three mana.

name: Monk of the Open Hand
lsvDescription: It's not too hard to get a 2/2 out of this, as you can just cast this before playing something else and be there already. Once it grows larger, you gotta hand it to him, as this will provide value over the course of the game. Flavor-wise, it's solid, and casting multiple spells as a way to represent the Flurry of Blows multiattack seems good to me.

name: Westgate Regent
lsvDescription: Westgate Regent threatens massive punishment if it ever hits the opponent, and the ward cost punishes them for targeting it too. That adds up to a great game-ender that gets you a two-for-one at the very least.

name: Shocking Grasp
lsvDescription: Shocking Grasp is the kind of card that you just don't end up having room for, as it's an inoffensive ability that doesn't cost you a card. Where I do like this is in UB, or any deck with a lot of must-block creatures, as that opens the door for a nice two-for-one.

name: Acererak the Archlich
lsvDescription: Acererak is both a Dungeon enabler and a payoff all in one, with the payoff part being quite hefty. Three mana isn't the worst deal to repeatedly escape, and a 5/5 that makes a 2/2 on attacks is fantastic. This also has great flavor, as Acererak really only shows up near the end of most campaigns, which this text does a good job of relating.

name: Vampire Spawn
lsvDescription: The games so far haven't played out in a way that's favorable to Vampire Spawn. It's not good on stalled boards and really needs aggressive support or equipment to shine, neither of which the decks I've drafted were able to provide.

name: Plate Armor
lsvDescription: Plate Armor is a bit clunky for most formats, as 3 + 3 is a lot of mana to sink into something that dies or gets bounced. It being cheaper to equip is not going to come up often, so this is a card I'd only play if my creature-heavy deck needed a finisher. As for flavor, Plate Armor often does get paired with a bunch of other gear, so I like the combo of abilities and protection this offers.

name: Wizard Class
lsvDescription: A Divination that costs an extra blue to start isn't the most exciting, but if you have time to get to level 3, this gives you a decent long term advantage. I'd play this in decks that have a good amount of card draw and want a finisher.

name: Eye of Vecna
lsvDescription: If you can afford the life loss, this is a solid draw engine. It's painful, so I'd try and play this in aggro decks or life gain decks primarily.

name: Divine Smite
lsvDescription: Despite the bit of extra flexibility, I still consider this a sideboard card. Phasing a creature out for a turn doesn't accomplish much, so you really only want this in your deck when facing black. As for the flavor, it's not the best, as this is supposed to represent a Paladin whacking someone, and not even specifically just evil things (though it does get a bonus when it does).

name: Underdark Basilisk
lsvDescription: Basilisks are pretty scary, what with the turning things to stone, and deathtouch definitely fits. This is a strong defensive two-drop, and even in aggro decks, this picks up Equipment well. It also works nicely with any fight/bite cards, and that makes it a solid pick anytime.

name: Hand of Vecna
lsvDescription: This is a beating in an aggro deck, assuming you draw it in your opener. Those two conditions preclude it from being great across the board, though I would play this in my aggressive decks and just hope to see it early.

name: Gelatinous Cube
lsvDescription: Gelatinous Cube is one of the most evocative D&D monsters, and this tells its story well, as it does consume things and dissolve them in its quivering mass. This also is awesome gameplay-wise, as it operates as a Banisher Priest that gives you the option of eating its target for good.

name: Treasure Vault
lsvDescription: This is another land I wouldn't play, as spending a ton of mana to make some Treasures is too marginal an ability to risk playing a colorless land.

name: Rust Monster
lsvDescription: This flavor would actually have fit better on Xorn, but it's alright here I suppose. The card is solid, as a 2/1 first striker brawls well and it doesn't take much before it can take down bigger things. This is at its best in the Treasure deck, though any aggro deck with a couple artifacts is likely interested.

name: Dwarfhold Champion
lsvDescription: In a deck with multiple pieces of Equipment, this will give you a great place to put them, and I definitely buy Dwarves getting better once they are geared up.

name: Ray of Frost
lsvDescription: I love this cycle of color hosers, and this is one of the better ones. As an instant-speed lockdown effect, this is cheap enough to make a big impact and it's unconditional removal against red. The 60/40 of good/great is pretty chill, and this is a card I'm always happy to play.

name: Treasure Chest
lsvDescription: I love the critical failure mode, though I agree it would have been bad to place that on more cards. This is a slow card drawing mechanism, and half the time you get a bunch of Treasures instead. I'd try this in slow decks, but am not high on it.

name: Valor Singer
lsvDescription: Valor Singer has done good work for and against me, as it gives you just enough power to open the door for some nice attacks. This is well worth playing in any aggressive deck.

name: Dragon's Disciple
lsvDescription: If you have four or more Dragons in your deck, this is a fine defensive option that gives them a little bit of extra protection. At one to three Dragons, this isn't reliable enough, and it's obviously terrible if you don't have any. The flavor isn't exciting, as I'm not sure how likely a disciple is to protect a Dragon from spells and all that.

name: Meteor Swarm
lsvDescription: Meteor Swarm is awkward on the colors, but a beating if you do cast it. The most common move will be to kill two or three creatures, though you could just nug one if you were really hard up. This would get a 4.5 if the mana cost was less intense, so in a deck with good mana, you should basically never pass it.

name: Check for Traps
lsvDescription: Checking for traps is a time-honored tradition, and in some cases, you do set them off while doing so (hence the life loss). This is a solid bit of disruption at low cost, and can let you take their best card and plan around the rest.

name: You Find the Villains' Lair
lsvDescription: I'm loving this flavor, and both choices tell a fantastic story. The card itself isn't very good, as Cancel or Faithless Looting is not an enticing combo. The idea is that if they don't play anything, you can use it to filter cards, but draw two discard two leaves you down a card overall. That's a deal breaker, so I guess I'll be thwarting some plans.

name: Iron Golem
lsvDescription: Iron Golems are nigh-indestructible, so making this die to anything with three power is a bit of a letdown. The fact that this has to block kills it for me, as it gives the opponent an easy out to trade up on mana for it.

name: Hobgoblin Bandit Lord
lsvDescription: This card is vastly improved by venture cards, as Lost Mine of Phalander gives you an easy way to make a Goblin, and most red decks can pick up a couple other Gobbos to boot. That makes this a solid lord/pinger combo, which is a great deal for three mana. I don't get the story of new Goblins showing up letting the Lord shoot things, but whatever.

name: Ranger's Hawk
lsvDescription: The tiny flyer slot in white used to always be terrible and now is always great, with Ranger's Hawk looking to continue that trend. It's a cheap flyer for Equipment and attacking, and can provide value over time if the board stalls. I like that combo, and the flavor works for me too, as your companion is leading you to adventures.

name: Deadly Dispute
lsvDescription: This is Village Rites with a twist, and I think it'll play well in this format. Being able to generate Treasure or sacrifice it helps with the Treasure decks, it's good in the morbid decks that want things to die and it can technically help ramp you to something big. It's not for every deck, but a couple color pairs will have decent synergy with it.

name: You Find Some Prisoners
lsvDescription: My adventuring parties definitely choose to interrogate most prisoners first (though they do ultimately release them, most of the time), making this flavor a solid hit. I've been happy playing it in most decks too, as it's basically a Shatter/Anticipate split card of sorts. Picking from the opponent's deck is certainly worse than yours, but it's still a good buyout if you have no artifact targets in sight.

name: Unexpected Windfall
lsvDescription: I haven't found room for this in most decks, as Contact Other Plane is better in UR, and RW and RG aren't interested in card draw at this cost. RB is the only combo that really wants this, and it will do solid work there.

name: You See a Guard Approach
lsvDescription: Tapping a creature isn't much, but hexproof is often worth a card, and that flexibility pushes this to “sometimes play.” It's great flavor too, though it's missing the option my party tends to take – slaughter the guard and take all their valuables.

name: Ranger's Longbow
lsvDescription: The Longbow is a bit clunky, but it does some real damage. It's at its best in long, grindy games, and luckily, the reach ability leads to those games. I'd be happy with this in any creature-heavy deck that needs some lategame, and it works well at enabling pack tactics too.

name: Hobgoblin Captain
lsvDescription: The Captain here is a good attacker if they don't have an early play, and becomes a great threat once it's got a little backup. This is one of the better two-drops for the pack tactics deck, and a solid addition to any aggro build.

name: Silver Raven
lsvDescription: There aren't enough artifact/flying synergies in the set to make me want a 1/1 flyer for one without much other upside, though I do like the callout to Figurine of Wondrous Power (an item that turns into a Silver Raven that scouts for you).

name: Bulette
lsvDescription: Bulette is solid in morbid/aggro decks, and mediocre outside of them. That means I wouldn't really prioritize it, as it's hard to land this shark in the right place.

name: Kalain, Reclusive Painter
lsvDescription: Kalain has been impressive. She fits perfectly into what RB is doing, and offers a strong enabler/payoff combo, which always is a hit. Your creature all end up pretty large if you have good ways to generate Treasure, and overall you get a ton for just two mana here. The story fits perfectly too, so it's even a flavor win.

name: Burning Hands
lsvDescription: Burning Hands is another strong part of the color hoser cycle, this time giving you Shock and Roast all in one. That's a card I'm happy playing, and this certainly feels like casting Burning Hands to me.

name: You Hear Something on Watch
lsvDescription: I like the flexibility here, as this fits nicely into a creature-heavy or defensive strategy, and both decks will benefit from having access to the “other” mode. The flavor is great too, though I can't say I've ever set traps while sleeping before.

name: Barbarian Class
lsvDescription: I've now put Barbarian Class into two dice-rolling decks, and both times it was not impressive. It just takes too many things going right before this has a good impact on the board, with the main problem being that the +2/+0 is hard to get to trigger at a time that does something. I'd pass on this class, even if the flavor is pretty good for Barbarians.

name: Mordenkainen's Polymorph
lsvDescription: It's almost never worth spending a card on this effect, as this doesn't make your things big enough or theirs small enough. I also don't love the flavor, as this card sucks and Polymorph is awesome.

name: Bard Class
lsvDescription: I like the flavor, as Bards do sing of legendary adventurers and their deeds. It's a blank for Limited, since every level involves having a lot of legendary cards.

name: Power of Persuasion
lsvDescription: This is the only d20 card that actually punishes you for rolling a 20, as taking their creature for a turn and a half is almost always worse than putting it on top or bottom of their deck. The fact that half the time this is a sorcery-speed bounce does not persuade me, and I'd avoid playing this. I also don't really get the story, as persuading something and bouncing it don't seem similar.

name: Portable Hole
lsvDescription: Removal that only kills small things is always fine in Limited, but never a really high priority. It's nice that this eats most Classes, as it can hit nonland permanents and not just creatures, but it's still not a bomb. Flavor-wise, I'm not thrilled, as Portable Holes aren't really something you can use in combat (though you could set up an elaborate trap, I suppose).

name: Steadfast Paladin
lsvDescription: Steadfast Paladin lives up to its name – it's a solid inclusion in any deck, with unremarkable but not inaccurate flavor.

name: Grim Wanderer
lsvDescription: Grim Wanderer is a great card for aggressive decks or morbid decks, and not something the average midrange or control will want. I love the tragic backstory, and enjoy how powerful this card is if you can enable it.

name: Vorpal Sword
lsvDescription: +2/+0 and deathtouch makes this a good aggressive threat, especially on tokens or first strikers, and the eight mana ability means they are forced to block later in the game. That's a solid set of abilities, and the flavor isn't bad either (Vorpal Swords decapitate your enemies when you roll a natural 20 on your attack roll).

name: Lurking Roper
lsvDescription: Lurking Roper is great in defensive decks, like UG ramp, and awesome in life gain decks. That makes it a fantastic early pick, even if aggressive decks will ultimately not be interested. Plus, Ropers are pretty burly, so this makes some sense flavorfully (though the life gain part doesn't really connect).

name: Goblin Morningstar
lsvDescription: Goblin Morningstar does an impressive amount of work for just about every color pair. It rolls dice, is good with pack tactics, is an Equipment and more. This has performed very well for me, giving you solid value to start with and a decent boost over the course of the game. It does look a little too shiny and well-kept to be a true Goblin morningstar, though.

name: Clever Conjurer
lsvDescription: In a deck looking to generate a lot of mana, Clever Conjurer is a decent ramp spell. The flavor doesn't quite track, as lazy wizards who cast Mage Hand aren't looking to do any actual work.

name: +2 Mace
lsvDescription: This is a little slow to get top marks, but it's a solid recurring threat in a slower game. As for flavor, a +2 Mace is a pretty big deal, and this is just alright.

name: Bag of Holding
lsvDescription: This is just too slow, and overall not worth fiddling with.

name: Ray of Enfeeblement
lsvDescription: Ray of Enfeeblement is a card I'm happy to main deck as a good combat trick and way to pick off X/1's, with the added bonus of being incredible against white decks. This is anything but feeble, and is a card I'm happy taking quite early.

name: Skullport Merchant
lsvDescription: The Merchant coming with the first Treasure goes a long way, and this has a fantastic rate plus a good long-term effect. I'm into it, and the flavor of a shady merchant that deals in Treasure or more comes across well.

name: Monk Class
lsvDescription: The combination of bouncing something plus doing weird fancy stuff definitely screams “Monk”, so the flavor is on point. This is a good early to midgame play as a bounce spell, followed by a strong late-game draw engine. Note that the exiled cards stay there as long as you want, so you don't have to play them the turn they are exiled.

name: Fifty Feet of Rope
lsvDescription: The tricks this rope does are just too slow and expensive overall, though I absolutely love the flavor.

name: Froghemoth
lsvDescription: Froghemoths are definitely a thing in D&D, and they do indeed swallow their enemies. This is a monstrous beater, and will often get the first hit in unimpeded, which then grows it and makes it harder and harder to stop. Ribbit.

name: Swarming Goblins
lsvDescription: I've been happy enough with Swarming Goblins when I want to generate die rolls or Goblins, as it does both on a consistent basis. It's a bit rough for UR that there are multiple good five-mana dice roll cards, as I have run into curve issues before.

name: Triumphant Adventurer
lsvDescription: Triumphant Adventurer is another great card for the BW Venture decks, and strong enough to play as your only venture card (though that's unlikely to happen based on the BW cards in the set). This can also trade for anything on defense and becomes unstoppable with any way to pump it.

name: Rally Maneuver
lsvDescription: Rally Maneuver looks absolutely brutal in any sort of large combat, and getting a two-for-one plus some life doesn't seem hard. It's less good if the board is small, so make sure your deck has a lot of creatures and plans to brawl. Flavor-wise, this sure is a combat maneuver.

name: Mordenkainen
lsvDescription: Mordenkainen is exactly the type of card you fear most, and those are the cards I want in my deck. A big, splashy mythic, Mordenkainen serves as a draw engine, a threat generator and a finisher, all in one. Ticking his loyalty up to seven immediately puts him out of reach of most attacks, and making a Dog that's a 4/4 or 6/6 most of the time is another good defensive measure. Every turn that Mordenkainen is in play, you're drawing cards or making Dogs, and after enough time, you can just draw your deck. Not much answers this, and even when you're behind, Mordenkainen is a huge play.

name: Air-Cult Elemental
lsvDescription: I'm definitely interested in using two of my six-drop slots on this (I have plenty, trust me), as it puts a big flyer into play while generating some delicious tempo. Bouncing a four or more-drop is an easy way to get ahead, and a 2/5 flyer is a real threat.

name: Boots of Speed
lsvDescription: Given that there's an Equipment theme in RW, these will be playable as an enabler if you need one. Past that, I'd take a walk, unless you want to speedrun your draft.

name: Scaled Herbalist
lsvDescription: I've tried the Herbalist, and the times where it works are few and far between. You need to draw this in your opening hand, alongside four or more lands and some decent plays. That's a tall order, and like DoorDash when you're really hungry, usually doesn't deliver.

name: Dragon's Fire
lsvDescription: Dragon's Fire has a lot of text to say “deal three damage”, which of course makes it a fantastic card. The flavor gets a pass too, as the clunky text does make it clear that your Dragon (if you have one) is breathing fire on them.

name: Wizard's Spellbook
lsvDescription: Having to pay for the spells this copies makes it way too slow for my tastes. It does nothing on seven mana, and if you wait until turn eight to play it, you only get the spell half the time. That means you have to just tap out for it on seven and hope you don't die, your reward getting to play your best spell (then your second best, and so on). I do like that rolling a 20 is an actual huge payoff, but the rest of this is just way too slow. A shame, since it does seem fun.

name: Aberrant Mind Sorcerer
lsvDescription: This is a high-stakes die roll, as you're losing a card if you roll low. I'd still play this in any deck that has enough spells, as it offers a powerful effect at a reasonable cost. It draws you a spell half the time, and if you lose the die roll, you can choose not to put the spell on top if you don't want to.

name: Warlock Class
lsvDescription: Warlock Class has a great first two levels, as you get a recurring ping effect plus a free card for only B + 1B. What really puts it over the top is that you can threaten to advance to the third level if the opponent ever lets damage through later, putting them in an awkward spot (especially if you're playing the morbid deck and want things to die). This is good in a deck with lots of creatures that plays for the long game, and solid in aggressive decks that just want the extra damage.

name: Rogue Class
lsvDescription: Rogue Class is interesting. You play it and start stacking exiled cards, but you don't get to play them until you level it to three. That makes it a bit slow and situational, but powerful when it works (and menace definitely helps get through). Like Rogues, this is complicated and won't always work out, but there are some good rewards when it does.

name: Krydle of Baldur's Gate
lsvDescription: Krydle has been solid, though not quite a bomb. You'll always be happy playing him, whatever your deck is doing, so he gets a lot of points for being easy to run. In the UB Saboteur deck, he can do good things, and overall this is a strong early pick.

name: You See a Pair of Goblins
lsvDescription: I can't get over how sweet the “You Encounter X” cards are, and this is no exception. This plays well, giving you either tokens or a mass pump, and the flavor is on point. Some of the best D&D memories are from befriending enemies you were expected to slay, and this captures that nicely.

name: Leather Armor
lsvDescription: Like Greataxe, this is not really exciting unless you need Equipment. The benefits are just too small, even if it is as cheap as it gets to equip.

name: Lolth, Spider Queen
lsvDescription: Lolth is a home run, eight thumbs up, and gets there on both mechanics and flavor. She puts a bunch of great blockers into play with her -3, which then feeds her loyalty thanks to her passive, and can draw cards if the board is stalled. The ultimate isn't crazy good, but the rest of her abilities are, so she still gets top marks.

name: Dueling Rapier
lsvDescription: This is similar to the Boots, though it does go up in value if you have a lot of first-strikers. The equip cost and effect just doesn't line up well, even if you get the first one for free.

name: Hunter's Mark
lsvDescription: Hunter's Mark is playable by itself, and absolutely disgusting against blue decks. That's a card I want in my deck, and am happy to take early. Almost all the cards in this set are bites, not fights, and that reduces the risk considerably.

name: Displacer Beast
lsvDescription: Displacer Beast is a cheap way to venture, both in terms of mana and resources. If the game drags on, it can start bouncing itself, and no matter what happens you got a very good deal. Good story, too.

name: Thieves' Tools
lsvDescription: If the game ever slows down, Thieves' Tools earn their keep. This works well in UB, or any deck playing saboteurs, and making a Treasure helps justify how slow this is.

name: Grim Bounty
lsvDescription: Grim Bounty is a fantastic removal spell that gives you a little mana rebate, while also offering color fixing and even ramp. Plus, the flavor is great, so there's not much more you can ask for from a common.

name: Soulknife Spy
lsvDescription: Soulknife Spy is a beating if you can back it up, and still solid if you use it to force a trade. It makes Shocking Grasp much stronger, and is a card I'm happy to play without combos and even happier to play with them.

name: Greataxe
lsvDescription: The not-so-Greataxe is an Equipment of desperation, as I'd only play it in RW decks that never found good gear.

name: Plummet
lsvDescription: Plummet is a solid sideboard card, as always, though I'm not getting much in the way of D&D flavor here.

name: Find the Path
lsvDescription: Green venture decks aren't the most common, and you want to be venturing and ramping for this to operate at max efficiency. Most decks won't want this, but the ones that do will be very happy with it.

name: Inspiring Bard
lsvDescription: Inspiring Bard is a neat crossover card, as it helps in life gain or aggressive/pack tactics decks. That's some good flexibility, and makes this a solid role-player for most green decks.

name: You Happen On a Glade
lsvDescription: I've had great success with this in ramp decks, as it fixes your mana and gives you more resources early, while being a very strong card late in the game. I really love that it's an instant, so you can get two lands on turn three on the draw and not have to discard. The flavor rocks too, making this a card I'm quite happy to see.

name: Moon-Blessed Cleric
lsvDescription: If you have some sick enchantments to get, this card is worth playing, though I would tend to avoid it otherwise. The flavor works too, making this a nice role-player.

name: Fighter Class
lsvDescription: Getting an Equipment off the bat helps here, and the level three ability can lead to some really good turns. This is worth playing in any deck that naturally wants Equipment, and like Bruenor, is not hard to enable. I'm lukewarm on the flavor, as the Equipment part makes sense but the taunting level three part doesn't (at least for me).

name: Lightfoot Rogue
lsvDescription: A 2/1 that always attacks with deathtouch and sometimes gets a power boost is pretty sweet, and this does well as a die roll card or a morbid card (or just a good attacker). My main quibble about flavor is that it's representing sneak attack, and you are just attacking and letting the opponent decide what to do.

name: Fates' Reversal
lsvDescription: I like the story of a fallen adventurer being brought back to continue venturing, and this plays out pretty well in game too. In the WB Dungeon decks, this is going to be quite strong, and at worst it's still a Raise Dead plus some value for only two mana.

name: True Polymorph
lsvDescription: Six mana is so much, even if this gives you a copy of the best creature or turns something of theirs into the worst creature in play (or a Treasure token). Too often, this won't be worth six, as it takes a bunch of other things to go right in order to be an effective play. That risk makes me not interested, even if the highs on this will be quite high.

name: Delina, Wild Mage
lsvDescription: There's a Splinter Twin-esque combo here with Pixie Guide, as each Guide you copy makes it more likely to highroll another one, and after five or six or so, you effectively go infinite. That's a sick combo, and definitely worth picking Pixie Guides for if you have Delina. Without the combo, she's still a big threat, and can open the door for some big attacks.

name: Mind Flayer
lsvDescription: If the opponent can't kill Mind Flayer, the game essentially just ends. It's so much value when left unchecked, and even if it dies after a few turns, you got a massive tempo boost. I'm slamming Mind Flayer whenever I see it, and to put the cherry on top, it perfectly captures what Mind Flayers feel like in D&D.

name: Guardian of Faith
lsvDescription: Guardian of Faith looks flashy, but will mostly play out as a 3/2 that you play at the end of their turn. Sometimes you'll protect a creature with removal and really get paid off, but this is expensive enough that it won't always line up that way. Flavor-wise, it's a protective spirit, which is definitely solid.

name: Sudden Insight
lsvDescription: Expensive draw spells aren't great to begin with, so adding an element of unreliability makes this suddenly unplayable.

name: Yuan-Ti Fang-Blade
lsvDescription: The Fangblade isn't easy to hit with, but it always trades, making it good on defense or offense. I'd mostly consider this a defensive card and morbid enabler, though the UB deck might be able to sneak it past the enemy as well.

name: Circle of the Moon Druid
lsvDescription: Circle of the Moon Druid is a solid beater and decent defender, making it an average inclusion for most decks. If you're focused on pack tactics, this does get better, as it gets you almost all the way there itself.

name: The Deck of Many Things
lsvDescription: The Deck of Many Things is incredible in any long game, and if you draft it, just build towards that goal. It's also pretty good as a curve-topper in an aggro deck, so what I'm trying to say is that the card is great. It provides a lot of resources for a reasonable cost, and when you spike a 20 you basically win – the idea is to reanimate their creature, and when that creature dies, so does your opponent.

name: Farideh's Fireball
lsvDescription: The miscalculated Fireball is a classic in D&D, and this burning you some of the time represents that well. The card is solid too, giving you removal with real upside in the dice rolling deck, and a little extra damage if you're aggressive.

name: You're Ambushed on the Road
lsvDescription: I'm a big fan of these modal cards, both because modal cards tend to play really well and because I love the flavor. This is a good combat trick or a way to save a creature, and the two choices line up flavorfully as well.

name: Skeletal Swarming
lsvDescription: Skeletal Swarming is the perfect card. It's powerful, hard to remove and really captures the flavor of being swarmed by a mass of Skeletons. You keep killing them and it keeps spawning more, they go from annoyance to threat to game-enders as the army grows, and in the end they overwhelm you. This is one of my favorite designs in the set.

name: You Come to a River
lsvDescription: Bounce is already really close to being playable, and just needs a little nudge to get it over the line. This provides that nudge, as long as your deck has some creatures it wants to get through, making it a solid spell and a great story.

name: Critical Hit
lsvDescription: Critical Hit might have the best flavor in the set, and is the cleanest at the very least. Crits deal double damage, and happen on a natural 20, so this really captures that essence. It's not a very strong card, as double strike is just okay, and getting this back won't really matter much.

name: Wild Shape
lsvDescription: Druids can Wild Shape into a wide variety of animals, so the flavor is good here, though usually those animal shapes are at least somewhat useful. These three options are all mediocre, with the hexproof one being the best by far. The stats this gives just aren't big enough, so I'd mostly look to side it in if I wanted some hexproof protection against removal.

name: Arborea Pegasus
lsvDescription: This is a solid aggressive creature that can push through damage and leave a good flyer behind. The flavor works too, as who doesn't like a nice Pegasus Lyft?

name: Split the Party
lsvDescription: My understanding is that you choose what to bounce, and it only targets the player, which does mean it can answer hexproof. That still doesn't make me want to play this, as it's a bounce one or two creatures most of the time, and not always in the situations you want.

name: Planar Ally
lsvDescription: You do need to want to venture a bit for this to be really appealing, as the five-mana 3/3 flying stat line is no longer a good one. I'm torn on flavor here, but ultimately don't see Planar Allies leading the party to new adventures as much as being something you can call on for help, so this doesn't do it for me.

name: Orcus, Prince of Undeath
lsvDescription: Orcus is an awesome split card, with three different modes, all great. You can cast him as a 5/3 flying trample for just four mana, a sweeper for six or more mana usually and a reanimation spell for even more mana. Three different modes, all of which come with a 5/3 flyer, and good at every stage of the game. Yep, that's bomb territory for me.

name: Clattering Skeletons
lsvDescription: Clattering Skeletons does its job well enough, providing a decent body and a little advancement on the dungeon track. If you can, having a Ghoul to eat this and get the trigger when you want is a good combo.

name: Gnoll Hunter
lsvDescription: As usual, two-drops are in short supply, and that makes Gnoll Hunter something worth prioritizing. If you can get to six power, this becomes a big threat, and even as just a dork that attacks on turn three, it does its job.

name: Spiked Pit Trap
lsvDescription: Pit Trap is mostly good for dice roll decks that need more ways to, well, roll the dice. It's too expensive outside of that.

name: Delver's Torch
lsvDescription: In a dedicated venture deck, this offers a reliable way to continue advancing through the Dungeon, even if it's not cheap. If you can dodge instant-speed removal, this should work out fairly well for you and eventually pays off big. The flavor text really hits home, giving this high flavor marks as well.

name: Dragon Turtle
lsvDescription: The stats here justify this already, though it does spend a turn being tapped down (even if they don't have any creatures, unfortunately). It using Drag Down when there are no targets is kind of weird, but otherwise the story checks out.

name: Contact Other Plane
lsvDescription: Contact Other Plane is a good draw spell for any deck that has the time for it. That seems like UR and UG more than anything else, especially with the d20 component, meaning it won't be snapped up too early in the draft. It is a whammy if you roll one through nine, as Inspiration is a lot worse than Glimmer of Genius, but the average of the two is still worth four mana. I do not like the flavor here, because the defining characteristic of Contact Other Plane is that you can strain your mind and take a bunch of psychic damage if you roll low, which isn't something this does.

name: Adult Gold Dragon
lsvDescription: Dragons are labelled by age, so the flavor/name works well here, as this is a large, scary threat that doesn't quite hit mythic levels. I'd be happy to splash this as well as just play it, since it's a huge game-changer when it lands.

name: Choose Your Weapon
lsvDescription: The combination of combat trick and Plummet is solid here, especially in decks with sizable creatures. I'd play this in any deck that expects to get into combat a lot, and would look to combine it with other pump spells for massive damage.

name: The Blackstaff of Waterdeep
lsvDescription: This is clearly a build-around, since you need a bunch of cheap artifacts to fuel it, but the prevalence of Treasure-generating cards makes me optimistic about what The Blackstaff will do. If you can rely on having two or three other artifacts a game, this is a big headache for the opponent, as it doesn't cost much to use and the artifacts become quite large. The flavor is great too, as animating statues is one of the Blackstaff's many powers (and I like that they kept it simple).

name: Secret Door
lsvDescription: Secret Doors definitely lead deeper into the dungeon, so the flavor is good, but I'm hesitant to put this into my deck. An 0/4 Wall isn't accomplishing much, and spending five mana to venture is not a good deal. I could see one of these sneaking in if you are all-in on venturing, but most decks won't be going that hard.

name: Keen-Eared Sentry
lsvDescription: The Sentry does a decent job of protecting you and guarding the Dungeon, though mostly it's a 2/1 that will die quickly (as sentries are one to do). Every now and then, you'll play against a venture deck and this will slow them down, but I don't think restricting them to once a turn will usually matter.

name: Bull's Strength
lsvDescription: The combat in Forgotten Realms lends itself to Bull's Strength being pretty solid, and as a result I'm giving it a higher rating than I would in a vacuum. The flavor is a bit of a miss for me, as even though Bull's Strength does increase strength, it's not really used during combat as much as precombat.

name: Neverwinter Dryad
lsvDescription: If you draw this in your opening hand, the curve is solid, but drawing it at almost any other point is bound to be disappointing. I've been unimpressed so far, and think the “never” part sums it up well.

name: Scion of Stygia
lsvDescription: I like the Scion a lot. It's comparable to a Frost Lynx, since even though you don't lock the creature down half the time, getting to play it at instant speed more than makes up for that. It also triggers your d20 cards, and is a good card for any blue deck.

name: Evolving Wilds
lsvDescription: Both these are essentially the same card, though the Temple has a lot more text. They are both five-color fixers where you choose a color and stick to it, and both are fine pickups for two-color decks (and critical for three or more color ones).

name: Priest of Ancient Lore
lsvDescription: I like the new direction of white getting cantrip creatures, and getting an extra life too is pretty sweet. I also totally buy Ancient Lore being life and cards here, so I'm just in for this card.

name: You Find a Cursed Idol
lsvDescription: This is one of my favorite cards in the set, flavor-wise, as all three modes just fit perfectly. As a card, it's a fine way to main deck artifact/enchantment removal, but venturing is also pretty narrow, as it's only good in dedicated decks. That makes this a little harder to just run, but solid in decks that care about venture.

name: Devour Intellect
lsvDescription: I'm already dubious of discard in Limited, because once it goes dead, it tends to stay dead the rest of the game (including when top-decked), and this spell in particular needs a Treasure to be playable. That gives you a pretty short window where it would be good, which makes it a card I'm not interested in playing.

name: Paladin Class
lsvDescription: I'm digging this, in part because of how much it mirrors Wrapter's paladin in our D&D game. The first level can definitely put a damper on combat tricks and removal, with the second level being strong and the third level being absurd. Paladins OP confirmed.

name: Black Dragon
lsvDescription: I like all the Dragons a lot (except the green one, spoilers), and this is one of the best ones. Black Dragon eats one of their creatures and leaves behind a massive threat, which is worth spending seven mana on.

name: Sylvan Shepherd
lsvDescription: Outside of life gain, this is basically a Riot Devils with minor upside, which isn't good enough. In the life gain deck, this is a zero-mana enabler, which is certainly valuable.

name: Death-Priest of Myrkul
lsvDescription: I really like this in the morbid deck or a deck with good sac outlets, as it can generate a lot of free value. Note that it sees deaths that occur even if it wasn't in play during combat, so attacking and trading and playing this afterwards works like a charm. The flavor obviously works too, as a Cleric summoning Skeletons when creatures die is a trope as old as time.

name: Feywild Trickster
lsvDescription: I really like the idea of a Fae that's generating more Fae based on randomness. The card looks quite strong too, and is one of the premier rewards for being in the d20 deck.

name: Pixie Guide
lsvDescription: In a die-rolling deck (d20 deck), this gives you a solid edge on making sure you're die rolls hit above nine (about a 78 percent chance with this out). It's also a decently-sized flyer, and definitely a card that deck is looking for. Outside the d20 deck, this is basically unplayable, so you shouldn't have much competition for it.

name: Sphere of Annihilation
lsvDescription: The feeling of impending doom, as the Sphere slowly advances and sucks all matter into its gaping maw – that I love. This hits the flavor note perfectly, and the one turn delay is a huge part of that. Sadly, that same delay makes this tough to get value from in Limited. Typically, you want the opponent to overextend into your sweeper, but when your sweeper takes an extra turn, you get hit for a lot of extra damage. The best use I can see is to play this to clean up small creatures while your big ones hold the fort, but I don't think that will come up often enough to make this great.

name: Mimic
lsvDescription: I love Mimics so much – you throw one into a campaign and your players will never trust a treasure chest again. This sadly isn't good enough to play, as neither mode is remotely worth the cost.

name: White Dragon
lsvDescription: The uncommon Dragon cycle is a nice mix of power and flavor, while being appropriate for uncommon. White Dragon adds a lot to the board, and is a great tempo play no matter what the situation is. Ice Breath is represented well here, and overall I like the card a lot.

name: Reaper's Talisman
lsvDescription: Reaper's Talisman looks awesome to me. You get to send in a creature every turn and drain them, and deathtouch forces a trade if they block. This looks best in a GB Morbid deck, but I'd play it in any deck that had a sufficient amount of creatures, with an eye towards making tokens or finding cantrip creatures to fuel the Talisman.

name: Flumph
lsvDescription: In a control deck specifically, I like Flumph. It doesn't give you a huge edge, but both players drawing sounds pretty good when you're trying to get to the lategame and hit your land drops on the way (plus, it's a solid defensive force as well). I really like the flavor, as Flumphs are these harmless things that float around the dungeon and benefit those who cross their path, which this certainly represents well.

name: Varis, Silverymoon Ranger
lsvDescription: Now this is an adventurer. Varis offers a great set of stats and abilities for only three mana, with secret reach and everything. The repeated venture ability is quite strong, and Varis will win most games where he stays in play for even a couple turns.

name: Celestial Unicorn
lsvDescription: In a life gain deck, this gets out of control quickly, and it's passable even if you never trigger it.

name: Guild Thief
lsvDescription: Guild Thief is a beating when you open on it, especially if you have some removal to push it through. Once it gets one counter, it becomes much harder to deal with, and it eventually starts to be worth just activating and attacking each turn. I like this in any aggressive deck and especially UB Saboteur, making it a good early pick.

name: The Tarrasque
lsvDescription: This is my biggest disappointment in the set. Just look at the entry for Tarrasque. It’s the biggest monster in the D&D universe, and is known to bring down entire civilizations by itself. This doesn’t feel like The Tarrasque (see, it even gets a “The”), and while this set is full of flavor win after flavor win, this isn’t one of them. It just doesn’t feel epic, and plays mostly vanilla while in play, so I’m left wanting more. Also, it costs nine mana, so probably don’t put this in your deck unless you’re incredible at ramp.

name: Barrowin of Clan Undurr
lsvDescription: Barrowin is a solid enabler and payoff both, which is exactly what the BW Venture deck wants. I've been impressed by her, and especially love getting back Cloister Gargoyle with her trigger.

name: Spoils of the Hunt
lsvDescription: Fighting over the spoils of the hunt sounds plausible to me, and the more treasure, the more heated the battle. This is a good removal spell for any green deck, and gets better if you have Treasure (though that is by no means necessary).

name: Green Dragon
lsvDescription: Green Dragon is easily the weakest of the cycle. It grants pseudo-deathtouch to your team for one turn, which is quite narrow, though it's still a 4/4 flyer.

name: Hulking Bugbear
lsvDescription: Hulking Bugbear is a great addition to any aggro deck, especially because of how good it is at enabling pack tactics. That deserves a good grade, even if there's nothing fancy going on here.

name: You Meet in a Tavern
lsvDescription: This is the classic start to every adventure, and I love that there's a card that represents it. The card itself isn't bad, as it finds creatures if you need them, and pumps them if you already have them. That's a good set of possibilities to cover, and this will do good work in a creature-heavy deck.

name: Hama Pashar, Ruin Seeker
lsvDescription: I've had mixed experiences with Hama. She's great when you're venturing into high-value rooms, but that's usually the challenge to begin with, and she ends up being a bit win-more as a result. Sure, doubling up on the last room in the Dungeon of the Mad Mage is awesome, but how often are you losing when you venture there in the first place? I'd play her in heavy venture decks, but I wouldn't look at Hama as a build-around worth taking early.

name: Teleportation Circle
lsvDescription: The vast majority of decks will not play this, as you need a bunch of good ETB abilities to make it worth it. If you do get two or three good ones and a couple more medium ones, I'd definitely get my teleportation on, but avoid it if you have less. Moving things around for little value does represent Teleport well, as in my experience, players who get high level enough to use it mostly harness the awesome power to go buy sweet rolls from their starting town or whatever.

name: Charmed Sleep
lsvDescription: I have no quibbles with this one, as it locks down a creature reliably and at reasonable cost, while also telling a solid story flavor-wise.

name: Loyal Warhound
lsvDescription: I really like cards that are better when you're on the draw, and this offers a sweet way to get some value. I totally don't get the flavor, as Dogs giving you land is weird, but at least the card is great.

name: Trelasarra, Moon Dancer
lsvDescription: Trelasarra is a solid piece of the life gain deck, as she pays you for gaining life and helps find your next piece. I'd play her with as few as three ways to trigger her, because you just need one counter and she becomes a good deal.

name: Inferno of the Star Mounts
lsvDescription: Inferno is a monstrous beating, attacking for a ton of damage immediately and usually finishing the game the turn after that. You aren't getting this to 20 power, but that doesn't matter, because they'll die rapidly to it. Inferno is also solid flavor, as this is a legendary Dragon that does legendary Dragon things, just like in the lore.

name: Gretchen Titchwillow
lsvDescription: Blue-green once again gets “ramp” as its theme, but I have to admit it's a fun theme. Gretchen is a good early blocker that takes over the mid to late game, and as such is a great early pick.

name: Ellywick Tumblestrum
lsvDescription: Ellywick has the distinction of being the planeswalker with the potentially strongest +1 ability in the game, as it technically can complete Dungeon of the Mad Mage if you're on the last room. That said, this is a decent way to generate card advantage but doesn't really protect itself (unless you're venturing into one of the rooms that does), making it weak when you're behind on board. I'd certainly be willing to take this and build around it, but it isn't a must-play bomb like many planeswalkers.

name: Ranger Class
lsvDescription: Ranger Class is another one of those cards where the opponent plays it on turn two and you mentally check out. It's so hard to beat, offering a strong early game, midgame and lategame. That checks all the boxes, and Rangers are pretty good in D&D, so this checks out.

name: Hive of the Eye Tyrant
lsvDescription: Lands that animate are always good, and all of these are strong additions to your deck. The white and blue ones are probably the best, and the black one is the worst, but realistically you should be taking and playing these all around third through fifth pick.

name: Grazilaxx, Illithid Scholar
lsvDescription: Illithids (also called Mind Flayers) are fearsome beasts, and tricky to boot. This captures that flavor well, as your creatures will jump in and out of play, while this draws you extra cards for your trouble. As long as you play plenty of creatures, and preferably evasive ones, this will do good work.

name: Kick in the Door
lsvDescription: Amazing flavor, decent power level and a card I get a kick out of every time I see it. This has utility in pack tactics deck by making surprise attackers, and can help you venture further if that's what your deck is trying to do.

name: Forsworn Paladin
lsvDescription: Forsworn Paladin is a cheap threat that generates Treasures as needed, which is already valuable, and the the pump ability makes it a nightmare for your opponent to navigate combat. This fits well into any deck, and especially well into RB Treasure, making it an early pick indeed. The flavor is a bit of a stretch, with the abilities representing finding Treasure and using evil spells to buff allies, I suppose?

name: Loathsome Troll
lsvDescription: I was skeptical on the Troll at first, given how easily it trades down, but after suffering a handful of losses to this, I'm higher on it. It just keeps on coming, and like Trolls tend to be, is nearly impossible to kill for good.

name: Targ Nar, Demon-Fang Gnoll
lsvDescription: Targ Nar is a beater, and is great on turn two or on turn 10, which always gets a high grade from me. You do want to be aggressive to use this, and it will deliver in any aggro strategy.

name: Dire Wolf Prowler
lsvDescription: The Prowler is one of those cards that ends games out of nowhere, and can attack unimpeded for the first 3-5 turns as well. That's a solid combination, and this does good work in aggro/pack tactics decks

name: Tiger-Tribe Hunter
lsvDescription: TTH here is a beating in any deck that can feed it, and has enough stats to get you to pack tactics with ease. I've been really impressed with the Hunter, and am happy to play it in any red deck.

name: Iymrith, Desert Doom
lsvDescription: Iymrith is a ridiculous bomb. This is unkillable until you attack, and if you suspect foul play, you can just choose to wait and leave Iymrith untapped. 5/5 flying for five with multiple good abilities is the cream of the crop, and easily one of the best cards in the set.

name: Precipitous Drop
lsvDescription: Drop it like it's hot, because it very much is. This removes small creatures early and big creatures late, and can sometimes sit in play before all of a sudden switching to -5/-5. Drop gives you value right away and is disgusting in a dedicated Dungeon deck, making it a premium common.

name: Instrument of the Bards
lsvDescription: This is a slow way to gain card advantage, but it does pull you ahead. I've had plenty of games where this would have been good, and if you can build a deck with enough defense, you can take full advantage of the Instrument. The flavor works for me too, as a Bard telling tales of legendary creatures is pretty sweet. Note that you can stop adding counters whenever you want, so you probably want this to sit on three or four for a while before ticking up.

name: Spare Dagger
lsvDescription: This works nicely with deathtouch creatures, but is a bit weak overall. Play only if you need Equipment or are short on removal.

name: Orb of Dragonkind
lsvDescription: I'm digging the flavor here, and the possibility of playing it in Constructed. Sadly, you will never get the five or six Dragons needed to put it in a 40-card deck.

name: Fly
lsvDescription: Fly looks awesome to me – evasion plus an on-hit ability is a great combo, and this will speedrun Dungeons if unanswered. You can almost always get one hit in if you pick your spot well, and backing this up with any kind of protection is likely game over. Flavor-wise, it works too, as flying ahead to explore is a legit plan.

name: Plundering Barbarian
lsvDescription: Plundering Barbarian is perfect. It provides good value no matter the situation, has awesome flavor and is cheap. You can't ask for much more.

name: Dancing Sword
lsvDescription: Dancing Sword would be a very strong Equipment without the ability to fly off and make its own way, so adding that is a nice power level bump. Equip 1 is just so cheap, and a 2/1 flyer with ward 1 is a nice annoyance when you need it to be. It's decent flavor, though most of the time you ideally have the Dancing Sword fighting alongside you, and not just after you die.

name: Prosperous Innkeeper
lsvDescription: This gives off some good vibes, both in flavor and mechanics. You just know this pleasant little Halfling has some great stew and ale going, and the inn is warm and comfy. This also plays out really well in ramp decks or life gain decks, making a card I'm happy to pick early.

name: Oswald Fiddlebender
lsvDescription: I had never heard of Oswald, but after reading, he appears to be a minor character in a few games. This card does seem true to his story, or true enough at least. As for the gameplay, this is mostly just a bear, but sometimes you'll get to use the ability, and it's pretty good when you do. Note that there are tons of ways to make Treasures, so picking up a one-drop is a good idea.

name: Paladin's Shield
lsvDescription: A solid bit of protection that gives you long-term value isn't bad for two mana, especially if you can draft enough creatures that your opponent really wants to block.

name: Druid Class
lsvDescription: Druid Class is excellent in life gain decks, as it provides a ton of triggers, and not worth it elsewhere. The land ramp ability will be useful once in a blue moon, and while the last level is quite strong, it's not worth playing the card if that's the only good mode for you.

name: Old Gnawbone
lsvDescription: Old Gnawbone is an avid treasure collector, and if other creatures aren't delivering, she'll get it herself. This is a gigantic flyer with upside of giving you nearly infinite mana, which I'm totally in for.

name: You Come to the Gnoll Camp
lsvDescription: You have to be pretty aggressive to want this, as both modes favor beatdowns, but I've definitely lost to it before and will do so again.

name: Cloister Gargoyle
lsvDescription: Cloister Gargoyle needs a little help to get its wings, but by itself gives you one venture and blocks well enough until you complete the Dungeon. This looks to me like one of the better venture payoffs, especially since the opportunity cost isn't that high. I actually like the flavor here too, as menacing gargoyles aren't always alive, and this being a wall sometimes and a monster other times lines up nicely with that.

name: Tasha's Hideous Laughter
lsvDescription: I'm not buying what this is selling. I can't imagine that it mills enough by itself to win the game, since there is basically no other support for it, and having a spell that immobilizes someone become a mill spell makes no sense flavor-wise either.

name: Goblin Javelineer
lsvDescription: Goblin Javelineer is high on my list of cards people love to play that don't accomplish much. This is passable in a really aggressive deck that has good Equipment, but outside of that it's mostly been an unblockable 1/1 for the first few turns, after which it's a blank.

name: Magic Missile
lsvDescription: I'm really pleased with Magic Missile, both for flavor and gameplay. It's a beating of a card, and an early frontrunner for the turn three groan test, as it wipes out two creatures a large percentage of the time. It also captures the essence of Magic Missile being powerful, (almost) uncounterable and able to be split onto multiple targets. Well done all around.

name: Shambling Ghast
lsvDescription: Shambling Ghast is the exact kind of card I love. It's as cheap as it gets, will often trade up on mana (since it can easily trade for most two-drops) and has utility even late in the game. Getting the Treasure option is great, and this is a card I'm happy to pick early and play multiple copies of.

name: Battle Cry Goblin
lsvDescription: I've been very impressed with the Battle Cry Goblin. It provides a lot of stats with haste, can generate tokens and leads to some pretty sick turns. This is better on turn six than turn two, which is a valuable property to have in a two-drop, and it's a card that would heavily push me towards a pack tactics deck.

name: Baleful Beholder
lsvDescription: I've yet to find room for Baleful Beholder, though I think it's a fine card if you're planning on attacking. Menace scales nicely, and I'd play this if I was missing top-end or needed a way to push through damage.

name: Bruenor Battlehammer
lsvDescription: Bruenor is one of the best reasons to go RW, which means he's doing his job as a signpost uncommon. You get a ton of stats and multiple relevant abilities for just four mana, as Equipment is easy to pick up and fairly strong in this set.

name: Chaos Channeler
lsvDescription: Chaos Channeler is like an Ardent Dustspeaker that costs less and doesn't require spells, which is a good place to be. It's a little disappointing that rolling a 20 doesn't do much more than 10 to 19, as you won't really be able to play all three cards in most cases.

name: Power Word Kill
lsvDescription: As the spell implies, this zaps just about anything that needs killing.

name: Rimeshield Frost Giant
lsvDescription: This is a very hard to kill five-drop, but the issue is more that the opponent won't really want to kill it. It's not huge, and at the stage in the game where it comes down, it's going to be outclassed one way or another.

name: Demilich
lsvDescription: Quad blue is a lot, and making this cheaper by playing spells won't usually be efficient. It's a good card once you land it, but most decks won't have the mana base necessary to do so.

name: Tiamat
lsvDescription: Tiamat is the god of evil dragons, and this card certainly evokes that. The casting cost is basically impossible, though if you do have a ton of Treasure making, sure, why not?

name: Djinni Windseer
lsvDescription: Sure, why not? This is a beefy flyer that gives you a little scry value plus a die roll, and will likely end up similar to Augury Raven from Kaldheim – solid, but not exciting.

name: Dungeon Descent
lsvDescription: I get the flavor here, but the text is so underwhelming that they must have been scared to push it. Either way, it's just too weak to consider playing.

name: Yuan-Ti Malison
lsvDescription: A repeatable way to trigger venture at extremely low cost is not something I'll pass on, and Yuan-Ti Malison is a fantastic card. The flavor also works, as Yuan-Ti Malisons are kind of tricky and roguelike in their own way.

name: Cleric Class
lsvDescription: Cleric Class doesn't blow me away on flavor or power level, though it will be good enough in a dedicated life gain deck. The last level is quite strong, I just don't like spending 10 mana to get there without getting value from the first two levels, and not every deck will be able to swing that.

name: Volo, Guide to Monsters
lsvDescription: Volo is a character who writes a book called Volo’s Guide to Monsters (as well as many other books) in the Forgotten Realms universe, and this is a great representation of him. He’s also a strong card, as with a little work on creature types, he generates tons of extra value for you. Volo into Owlbear is the dream, but copying anything will be great.

name: Price of Loyalty
lsvDescription: The vast majority of decks won't be able to use this, as stealing a creature for a turn really isn't that effective unless you are about to kill them. However, there are enough sacrifice effects that you will occasionally be able to build a RB Sac deck, at which point the price is right.

name: Ingenious Smith
lsvDescription: I don't think you're going to have the artifact count to ever play this in Limited (you'd want over eight to even think about it), but it's an interesting card for Constructed. The flavor is good, though the smith eventually becoming a 5/5 or something starts to break the analogy.

name: Hired Hexblade
lsvDescription: In a deck that generates a lot of Treasure, this is a solid curve-filler. If you don't have the option to pay the gold price, I'd avoid running this. The whole Treasure = bribe thing is pretty good, so I definitely approve of the flavor.

name: Flameskull
lsvDescription: Flameskull is hot, and one of the cards that some decks basically can't beat. You can exile it, you can attack past it and you can maybe hold it off with a x/4 flyer, but that's about it. I'm happy taking this one early and trying to draft a beatdown deck around it.

name: Den of the Bugbear
lsvDescription: Lands that animate are always good, and all of these are strong additions to your deck. The white and blue ones are probably the best, and the black one is the worst, but realistically you should be taking and playing these all around third through fifth pick.

name: Jaded Sell-Sword
lsvDescription: I still love the hired gun flavor here, and the card itself is fine if you can reliably generate Treasure.

name: Feign Death
lsvDescription: Feign Death is a passable trick if you need one, and combines especially well with ETB abilities. It won't be hard to pick one of these up if you want one, which shouldn't be all that often.

name: Improvised Weaponry
lsvDescription: The first one of these is usually pretty good, but they do fall off in multiples (unless you're the Treasure deck, in which case grab as many as you can get). I also think golden idols tend to be worth less after using them as a mace, but the flavor is solid.

name: Hoarding Ogre
lsvDescription: The Ogre fits well enough into UR or RB, as it works with both themes, but it's not a premium common. It's playable if you need it, and will rarely show up in RB or RW.

name: Farideh, Devil's Chosen
lsvDescription: Farideh is a solid payoff for the dice-rolling deck, though I'm not super high on that deck overall. The best way I've found to approach it is to play the good die roll cards and payoffs like this one, but avoid the weaker payoffs like Brazen Dwarf. Either way, Farideh is a strong card, even if this deck doesn't always come together.

name: Zalto, Fire Giant Duke
lsvDescription: Zalto definitely brings home the bacon, as he will basically always trade for a card, some damage and venture, with there being the potential for much more. Combat tricks work really well here, as do removal spells, making Zalto a giant threat. The one flavor issue I have is the low toughness – Fire Giants are not trivial to kill.

name: Shessra, Death's Whisper
lsvDescription: Shessra will often draw a card the turn you play her, and then intermittently afterwards. She's good when paired with removal or life gain, and overall is a solid card.

name: Long Rest
lsvDescription: A long rest is what you do once you've finished a fight, and you recover all your spells and abilities (as well as hit points). That makes this a flavor win, even if the card is way too expensive and situational to actually be good.

name: The Book of Vile Darkness
lsvDescription: As good as the flavor is here, the effect is quite weak. You aren't getting Zombies very often, and assembling the trio of cards is nigh-impossible in Limited.

name: Manticore
lsvDescription: Manticore is at its best in a couple scenarios: You're playing the UB Saboteur deck and you have a lot of must-block attackers, or you have a deck that has a lot of instants (like Contact Other Plane) and can afford to keep mana up for it on their turn. Outside of those, this can be a bit tough to use, making it a solid card rather than a great one.

name: Red Dragon
lsvDescription: Red Dragon does good work, giving you a huge flyer and a down payment of four face damage. I'm a little underwhelmed by the flavor, as Red Dragons are the most iconic of all D&D monsters, and this doesn't capture that (thought it's solid to be sure).

name: Intrepid Outlander
lsvDescription: Intrepid Outlander offers a great body for attacking or blocking, and the pack tactics ability is a strong one. I like this, and especially would prioritize it in a deck that cares about venturing.
